snippet.textDisplay: Well I had corona June last year and I donated blood this may and I still have plenty of anti bodies. Blood bank called me to donate again for anti bodies.
snippet.textOriginal: Well I had corona June last year and I donated blood this may and I still have plenty of anti bodies. Blood bank called me to donate again for anti bodies.

snippet.textDisplay: @Eclypse Dex no I had it once, in January of 2020 and showed antibodies in June of 2020 still. Then in June of 2021 (annual blood work), I still was positive for Covid antibodies. I’m not sure if I was exposed more than once but I only had symptoms once. They were tight chest, cough, worst part for me was fever. Four days of the highest fever I’ve ever had. My husband had totally different symptoms. He had fever but he had dizziness (like extreme dizziness- couldn’t walk down the hall without falling to the floor), upset stomach and vomiting. He hasn’t had his antibodies tested but mine are still there.
snippet.textOriginal: @Eclypse Dex no I had it once, in January of 2020 and showed antibodies in June of 2020 still. He had fever but he had dizziness (like extreme dizziness- couldn’t walk down the hall without falling to the floor), upset stomach and vomiting. He hasn’t had his antibodies tested but mine are still there.

snippet.textDisplay: @Coral Uru You had Covid-19 twice? Did you get very sick?
snippet.textOriginal: @Coral Uru You had Covid-19 twice? Did you get very sick?

snippet.textDisplay: I had it in January, 2020 and in June, 2021, I was still positive for antibodies.
snippet.textOriginal: I had it in January, 2020 and in June, 2021, I was still positive for antibodies.

snippet.textDisplay:
​@Böser.Stachel the question of antibodies is a bit ambiguous. Our immune system has several layers and antibodies are just one part of it. They mostly die off after a certain period of time if there is no infection. However, memory cells which are also part of our immune bodies store information about each pathogen they encounter. Once they "see" it again, they send a chemical signal to the rest of the immune system which begins to produce necessary antibodies to combat that specific pathogen. So antibodies do disappear with time, but it does not mean that our bodies are unprepared for a subsequent infection by the same pathogen. 



With influenza viruses, the problem is that they mutate too quickly to the point where our bodies stop recognising them, but you remain virtually immune to the same strain. There is a certain concern that SARS-Cov-2 might turn into a rapidly mutating virus, just like influenza viruses are. If it happens, we will likely need vaccine shots each time a new strain appears as it currently happens with the flu.

snippet.textDisplay: @Bob Man well I know you don’t donate for antibodies specifically but after corona they test blood for antibodies of corona. In my case they found antibodies and called me to come donate again.
snippet.textOriginal: @Bob Man well I know you don’t donate for antibodies specifically but after corona they test blood for antibodies of corona. In my case they found antibodies and called me to come donate again.

snippet.textDisplay: You don't donate blood for antibodies. But it's good you donate. Not everyone can and it's always in demand.
snippet.textOriginal: You don't donate blood for antibodies. But it's good you donate. Not everyone can and it's always in demand.

snippet.textDisplay:
uncommon for antibodies to last a year.

It's nice that you donate blood.  Personally, my life was saved by donated blood.
snippet.textOriginal:
uncommon for antibodies to last a year.

It's nice that you donate blood.  Personally, my life was saved by donated blood.

snippet.textDisplay: Possibly you encountered more of the virus in the past six months and got a natural booster while remaining asymptomatic.  Perhaps this happened multiple times so your antibodies never decreased.  Antibodies are present for an undetermined period of time after an infection has ended but a year seems quite long.  Serological test results should be interpreted with caution.
